bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Darrell C. Crain, January 8, 1942

div1.p: Hench requests permission to borrow a movie projector from Crain.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Darrell C. Crain, January 8, 1942

opener.dateline:
January 8, 1942 Dr. Darrell C. Crain
1150 Connecticut Avenue
Washington, D. C.

div1.p:
This may seem like a strange request but you are the sort of a
person from whom one asks strange requests:

Mary and I are arriving in Washington at the Willard Hotel next
Tuesday, to be there a few days. Part of it is in connection with the
placing of members of the American Rheumatism Association in favorable
military positions if and when we are needed. That will take a day or
two for me to see the appropriate people with whom I have appointments--
the heads of the personnel departments of the army and navy medical corps
and the head of the procurement division. However, I will be adding three
or four days just as a personal vacation, poking around the National
Archives and other places in connection with a historical study that I
am making on the conquest of yellow fever. I am sending you by separate
post a reprint which explains my interest.

Now to get to the point. I expect to see Mrs. Walter Reed, General
Kean, General Ireland and others and if I can get them together sometime
I want to show them the movies I took in Havana. I was about to bring my
own projector and screen but it is must too much to carry and I wonder if
I could telephone you some day and borrow one that you may have--a 16 milli-
meter projector and screen. With a baby in your house I suspect that you
are an amateur movie fan. I would really very greatly appreciate borrowing
this.

Have you ever met Mrs. Walter Reed or General Ireland? If not,
I should like to have you meet them.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
